en.value: I was revising for my exam
Talking about our studies, past and present - Past continuous

When we are learning or studying, we spend time discussing, reviewing and making sure we understand different topics. The words and phrases that we use in these contexts are what we are now going to focus on. So, we'll look at how to say things like:
Today, we were discussing George Orwell.
She has lots of work at the moment.
I'm up to my eyeballs in work right now!
I'm drowning in emails at the moment!
In English, we have many different words and expressions relating to having a lot of work. Some colloquial expressions we can say when we have lots of work are:
Camila finished her exams last week.
I finished my exams last week, but I have lots of work on right now.
We were revising for the language test on Friday.
Match the beginning and end of each sentence.
Listen to the dialogue. What was Mina doing yesterday evening?
We had a few classes together last year.
We had a few [k]classes[/k] together last year.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I don't [k]u[/k]n[k]d[/k][k]e[/k][k]r[/k][k]s[/k]ta[k]n[/k][k]d[/k] the topic of the paper.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Match the beginning and the end of each sentence.
To recap, here are the words and expressions we've just seen:
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Hi. I'm good, a little tired, though. I [k]was revising[/k] for most of last week. I'm [k]drowning in exams[/k] right now! What are you up to today?
Oh no! Well, good luck for your exams. I'm meeting Clara for lunch. Do you remember her? We all [k]had a class[/k] together last year.
Thank you! Yeah, I remember her! I like her, she's really friendly.
Yeah, she's great. Do you fancy joining us for lunch?
I can't, sorry! I [k]have lots of work[/k] to do. Next time!
Listen to the dialogue. What was Alex doing yesterday?
He was revising for an exam.
I'm up to my [k]eyeballs[/k] in work right now!
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Last week we were [k]discussing[/k] verbs in my English class.
We [k]had[/k] a few classes together last year.
Listen to the dialogue. Select the most accurate statement.
Mika doesn't understand the text and Lou is offering him help.
Lou didn't like the article and she needs Mika to explain it to her.
Mika has lots of work at the moment but has no exams coming up.
I [k]have lots of work[/k] right now.
Match the word with its definition.
to prepare for an exam or read / practise something again
to talk about a topic in detail
to know the meaning of something / know a topic well
I was very busy at the office I couldn't [k]revise[/k] for my test.
Verb that means "to prepare for an exam".
Fill in the gap using the hint.
The topic of this article is so difficult, I don't [k]understand[/k] it.
Tell the busuu community about your job or studies. Do you have lots of work to do at the moment? What's been keeping you busy recently?
I have lots of ... at the moment. / I'm up to my ... in work right now! / I was ... for an exam last week.
Time for a new past tense: the past continuous!
We use the past continuous tense to talk about actions that were in progress in the past.
This sentence expresses an action that was in progress in the past.
I was driving to my parents' house last weekend.
Another use of the past continuous is to talk about what was happening around a certain time.
What were you doing this time last year?
This time last year I was living in Spain with my parents.
Select the two words that form the past continuous in this sentence.
Finally, we can use the past continuous for actions that were in progress in the past, which were interrupted by another action (usually in the past simple).
You were living in London when you met your husband.
I was showering when you called me.
I was [k]living[/k] with my parents when I [k]got[/k] my first car.
Complete the sentence with the past continuous followed by the past simple.
We form the past continuous with two parts: the past simple form of the verb "to be" (was / were), followed by the -ing form of the main verb.
All verbs in this tense follow the same pattern as the present continuous. The only difference is that the verb "to be" is in the past and not the present.
Select the words in the correct order.
To form negative sentences in the past continuous tense, we insert the word "not" after "was / were" and before the -ing verb. We can also use shortened forms in the past continuous.
I was not talking to you. = I wasn't talking to you.
They were not living together. = They weren't living together.

To form questions in the past continuous tense, all we have to do is swap "was / were" with the person / thing doing the action. We can also add a wh-question word to the beginning to ask different kinds of questions.
Who was using the bathroom for ages last night?
Were you [k]working[/k] from home on Tuesday?
[k]Where[/k] were you [k]studying[/k] today? The library was full!
[k]What were you doing[/k] this time last year?
